\chapter{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{index:introduction}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Parallel.GAMIT is a Python wrapper to parallelize GAMIT executions.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Parallel.GAMIT is a Python software solution for parallel GPS processing of large regional or global networks. It also incorporates a metadata and RINEX data management tool that guarantees a consistent archive. It relies on Postgres SQL (\sphinxurl{https://www.postgresql.org/}) to store station metadata and the GPSPACE Precise\sphinxhyphen{}Point\sphinxhyphen{}Positioning (PPP) software (not included in this repository, available here: \sphinxurl{https://github.com/CGS-GIS/GPSPACE}) to obtain reliable daily a\sphinxhyphen{}priori coordinates for GAMIT.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The software is divided into two modules: Parallel.GAMIT (PG) and Parallel.PPP (PP). PG requires all GAMIT\sphinxhyphen{}GLOBK (\sphinxurl{http://www-gpsg.mit.edu/~simon/gtgk/}) dependencies installed in the processing nodes. PP requires GPSPACE PPP and several other dependencies detailed later in this document. Although PP was designed to use GPSPACE PPP, it can be easily changed to use any other open source PPP software such as RTKLIB (\sphinxurl{http://www.rtklib.com/}), although this has not been tested.

\sphinxAtStartPar
PG uses dispy (\sphinxurl{https://github.com/pgiri/dispy}) to create Python pickles that are sent to local or remote nodes for execution. PG has the ability to split a network of GPS stations into subnetworks for processing in GAMIT (when the network is larger than 50 stations, depending on PG’s configuration). The parallel execution is performed per day\sphinxhyphen{}subnetwork. In other words, a GAMIT pickle is built for each subnetwork\sphinxhyphen{}day being processed and sent to the available nodes. At the end of each PG run, the subnetworks are combined with GLOBK and inserted as records in the Postgres database for later use. Some routines (such as the SINEX parser) are modified versions of the code from @softwarespartan (\sphinxurl{https://github.com/softwarespartan}).

\sphinxAtStartPar
PP is a Python wrapper for the PGSPACE PPP which uses the same Postgres SQL database to store the daily PPP solutions and medatadata of all station\sphinxhyphen{}days in the GPS archive. Some of the abilities of PP are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Scan a directory structure containing RINEX files and add them to the Postgres database (DB).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Manage station metadata in GAMIT’s station info format with consistency check of the records.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add new RINEX data to the database by geolocation, i.e. the data is incorporated not by station name but by running PPP and finding the corresponding station in the DB. This avoids problems with duplicate station codes and misidentified RINEX files.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Handle ocean loading coefficients to correct the PPP coordinates and produce consistent time series before running GAMIT. This allows to find problems in the metadata BEFORE executing a long GAMIT run.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Plot PPP time series using Bevis and Brown’s (2014) extended trajectory model.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Merge stations with different names that in reality are the same station (but renamed or moved a couple of meters), if desired.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Merge, delete and add metadata directly from GAMIT station info files or using UNAVCO’s GSAC (\sphinxurl{https://www.unavco.org/software/data-management/gsac/user-info/user-info.html}).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Parse all ZTD results and store them in the database.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Stack the GAMIT solution to produce regional or global reference frames following Bevis and Brown’s (2014).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Both PP and PG tolerate station name duplicates by using a three\sphinxhyphen{}letter network code. Although this is not supported by GAMIT, PG converts duplicate station codes (stored in different networks) to unique IDs that are used during processing, which are later converted back to the original names after the GLOBK combination of the subnetworks.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Because all the information is stored in a relational database, PP and PG can handle very large datasets very easily (it has been tested with \textasciitilde{} 5,600,000 station\sphinxhyphen{}days but Postgres can easily handle more than 10 million records in a regular computer). Also, the relational database guarantees then consistency of the data and does not allow accidental duplicates in metadata.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
PG and PP require the following dependencies:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Python version \textgreater{} 3

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
GAMIT\sphinxhyphen{}GLOBK: although PP does not use GAMIT to process data, it relies on grdtab, otl.grid and sh\_rx2apr to obtain the ocean loading coefficients and station coordinates (when PPP fails to process a station\sphinxhyphen{}day). Bare in mind that sh\_rx2apr needs the following dependencies to run in a computer without GAMIT installed: svdiff, svpos, tform, sh\_rx2apr, doy

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
gfzrnx: RINEX quality check and conversion tool which supports RINEX 3.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
pygressql: Python interface to connect to Postgres

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
tqdm: a Python progress bar to show the processing progress

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
rnx2crx: RINEX to CRINEX

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
crx2rnx: CRINEX to RINEX

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
crz2rnx: this is a script modified by me which is based on the the scripts found in \sphinxurl{http://terras.gsi.go.jp/ja/crx2rnx.html} with a few minor tweaks to handle the most common problems found in CRINEZ files.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
rnx2crz: the regular C\sphinxhyphen{}shell script

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
compress/gzip

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
dispy to schedule parallel jobs

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
matplotlib

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
numpy

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
scandir

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Neicio: the USGS NEIC Python interface and its dependencies found in \sphinxurl{https://github.com/usgs/neicio}

\end{itemize}

\index{copyfile() (in module classes.Utils)@\spxentry{copyfile()}\spxextra{in module classes.Utils}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.Utils.copyfile}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.Utils.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{copyfile}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{src}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{dst}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{rnx\_ver}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{2}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Copies a file from path src to path dst.
If a file already exists at dst, it will not be overwritten, but:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If it is the same as the source file, do nothing

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If it is different to the source file, pick a new name for the copy that
is different and unused, then copy the file there (if rnx\_ver=2)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If because rinex 3 files have names that are more comprehensive (include start time and duration)
if a rnx\_ver == 3 then copy the file unless it already exists (in which case it does nothing)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns the path to the copy.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{move() (in module classes.Utils)@\spxentry{move()}\spxextra{in module classes.Utils}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.Utils.move}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.Utils.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{move}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{src}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{dst}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Moves a file from path src to path dst.
If a file already exists at dst, it will not be overwritten, but:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If it is the same as the source file, do nothing

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If it is different to the source file, pick a new name for the copy that
is distinct and unused, then copy the file there.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns the path to the new file.

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{classes.pyArchiveStruct module}
\label{\detokenize{classes:module-classes.pyArchiveStruct}}\label{\detokenize{classes:classes-pyarchivestruct-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!classes.pyArchiveStruct@\spxentry{classes.pyArchiveStruct}}\index{classes.pyArchiveStruct@\spxentry{classes.pyArchiveStruct}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Project: Parallel.Archive
Date: 02/16/2017
Author: Demian D. Gomez

\sphinxAtStartPar
This class handles the interface between the directory structure of the rinex archive and the databased records.
It can be used to retrieve a rinex path based on a rinex database record
It can also scan the dirs of a supplied path for d.Z and station.info files (the directories and files have to match the
declared directory structure and \{stmn\}\{doy\}\{session\}.\{year\}d.Z, respectively)
\index{RinexStruct (class in classes.pyArchiveStruct)@\spxentry{RinexStruct}\spxextra{class in classes.pyArchiveStruct}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{ }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyArchiveStruct.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{RinexStruct}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{cnn}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}
\index{build\_rinex\_path() (classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct method)@\spxentry{build\_rinex\_path()}\spxextra{classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct.build_rinex_path}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{build\_rinex\_path}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{NetworkCode}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{StationCode}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{ObservationYear}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{ObservationDOY}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{with\_filename}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{True}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{filename}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{rinexobj}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Function to get the location in the archive of a rinex file. It has two modes of operation:
1) retrieve an existing rinex file, either specific or the rinex for processing
(most complete, largest interval) or a specific rinex file (already existing in the rinex table).
2) To get the location of a potential file (probably used for injecting a new file in the archive. No this mode,
filename has no effect.
:param NetworkCode: NetworkCode of the station being retrieved
:param StationCode: StationCode of the station being retrieved
:param ObservationYear: Year of the rinex file being retrieved
:param ObservationDOY: DOY of the rinex file being retrieved
:param with\_filename: if set, returns a path including the filename. Otherwise, just returns the path
:param filename: name of a specific file to search in the rinex table
:param rinexobj: a pyRinex object to pull the information from (to fill the achive keys).
:return: a path with or without filename

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{get\_rinex\_record() (classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct method)@\spxentry{get\_rinex\_record()}\spxextra{classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct.get_rinex_record}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_rinex\_record}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Retrieve a single or multiple records from the rinex table given a set parameters. If parameters are left empty,
it wil return all records matching the specified criteria. Each parameter acts like a filter, narrowing down the
records returned by the function. The default behavior is to use tables rinex or rinex\_proc depending on the
provided parameters. E.g. if Interval, Completion and Filename are all left blank, the function will return the
records using rinex\_proc. Otherwise, the rinex table will be used.
:param NetworkCode: filter
:param StationCode: filter
:param ObservationYear: filter
:param ObservationDOY: filter
:param Interval: filter
:param Completion: filter
:param Filename: filter
:return: a dictionary will the records matching the provided parameters

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{insert\_rinex() (classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct method)@\spxentry{insert\_rinex()}\spxextra{classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyArchiveStruct.RinexStruct.insert_rinex}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{insert\_rinex}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{record}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{rinexobj}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Insert a RINEX record and file into the database and archive. If only record is provided, only insert into db
If only rinexobj is provided, then RinexRecord of rinexobj is used for the insert. If both are given, then
RinexRecord overrides the passed record.
:param record: a RinexRecord dictionary to make the insert to the db
:param rinexobj: the pyRinex object containing the file being processed
:param rnxaction: accion to perform to rinexobj.
:return: True if insertion was successful. False if no insertion was done.

\end{fulllineitems}

:return: a list containing the network code, station code and dates of the outliers in the time series

\end{fulllineitems}

credits {[}2{]}.

\subsection{classes.pyOkada module}
\label{\detokenize{classes:module-classes.pyOkada}}\label{\detokenize{classes:classes-pyokada-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!classes.pyOkada@\spxentry{classes.pyOkada}}\index{classes.pyOkada@\spxentry{classes.pyOkada}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Project: Parallel.GAMIT
Date: 5/15/24 9:08 AM
Author: Demian D. Gomez

\sphinxAtStartPar
Seismic\sphinxhyphen{}score (s\sphinxhyphen{}score) class that allows testing if a latitude longitude locations requires co\sphinxhyphen{}seismic
displacement parameters on its ETM. The class includes the formulations from Wells and Coppersmith (1994) to
estimate the fault dimensions of the event and calculate the level\sphinxhyphen{}2 s\sphinxhyphen{}score. If the nodal planes of the event
are not available, then the class returns the level\sphinxhyphen{}1 (isotropic) s\sphinxhyphen{}score.


\subsubsection{Okada code Translated from Matlab to Python. Original by Michael Bevis based on Okada 1985}
\label{\detokenize{classes:okada-code-translated-from-matlab-to-python-original-by-michael-bevis-based-on-okada-1985}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
OKADA surface displacements due to dislocation in an elastic half\sphinxhyphen{}space This is a matlab implementation of Okada’s
fortran code SRECTF except that only surface displacements are computed, not strains or tilts. See document
OkadaCoordSystem.pdf by M. Bevis for graphics describing of Okada’s (1985) coordinate systems and sign conventions

\sphinxAtStartPar
USAGE:    {[}ux,uy,uz{]} = okada(alpha,x,y,d,L1,L2,W1,W2,snd,csd,B1,B2,B3)

\sphinxAtStartPar
A rectangular dislocation is located in an elastic halfspace. The right\sphinxhyphen{}handed coordinate system \{X,Y,Z\} has Z positive
upwards, and the X and Y axes lie on the surface of the halfspace. The upper and lower edges of the rectangle are
horizontal and parallel to the X axis, which constitutes the ‘strike direction’. The rectangular dislocation is located
within a dipping plane which intersects the Z axis at \sphinxhyphen{}d (so d is a positive number coinciding with ‘depth’). The dip
of this plane is the angle delta which is measured positive anticlockwise from horizontal looking in the \sphinxhyphen{}X direction,
as seen in Figure 1 of Okada’s 1985 BSSA paper. The user must specify sd = sin(delta) and cd = cos(delta) rather than
delta itself, since this convention allows a general treatment of the vertical fault (switching sd between +1 and \sphinxhyphen{}1
when cd = 0, changes which side of the fault is going up). The position of the dislocation within the dipping plane is
specified using a cartesian axis system \{L,W\} confined to the plane of the dislocation, with the L axis being parallel
to and located beneath the X axis. The origin of the \{L,W\} system is at X=Y=0, Z=\sphinxhyphen{}d. The actual dislocation is located
in the rectangle L1 \textless{}= L \textless{}= L2, W1 \textless{}= W \textless{}= W2.

\sphinxAtStartPar
With reference to Okada (1985) Figure 2, the fault outlined with a solid line has L1=0,L2=L, W1=0, W2=W. To specify the
extended fault shown with the dashed line, change L1 to \sphinxhyphen{}L.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Burgers vector B for the dislocation has three components B1,B2 and B3 where B1 is the L component, B2 is the W
component, and B3 is the component normal to the dislocation surface.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The elastic half\sphinxhyphen{}space (Z\textless{}0) is uniform and isotropic. The displacement field produced by the dislocation depends only
on scalar alpha, where alpha = mu/(lambda+mu). When the Lamé parameters lambda and mu are equal, the elastic is said to
be a Poisson solid and alpha=0.5

\sphinxAtStartPar
The stations where displacememts are to be computed have coordinates x and y (which can be scalars, vectors or
matrices, but must have the same sizes. THe output arguments ux, uy and uz, which have the sames sizes as input
arguments x and y, are the X, Y and Z components of displacement at each station.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Okada.m uses internal matlab function okadakernel.m to peform the indefinite integrals.

\sphinxAtStartPar
version 1.0               Michael Bevis                  4 Nov 99
version 1.1                                             26 Feb 04
version 1.2  (change argument names, new header)        11 Oct 13
version 1.3  (changed sd,cd too)                         3 Apr 14
version 1.0  (PYTHON) translated by Demian Gomez        15 May 24

\sphinxAtStartPar
Given a connection to the database, lat and lon of point of interest, and date range, find all the seismic events
with level\sphinxhyphen{}2 s\sphinxhyphen{}score = 1. If no strike, dip, and rake parameters available, return events with level\sphinxhyphen{}1 s\sphinxhyphen{}score \textgreater{} 0
Returns a list with {[}mag, date, lon, lat{]} ordered by ascending date and descending magnitude.

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyPPP.PPPSpatialCheck}}

\subsection{classes.pySp3 module}
\label{\detokenize{classes:module-classes.pySp3}}\label{\detokenize{classes:classes-pysp3-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!classes.pySp3@\spxentry{classes.pySp3}}\index{classes.pySp3@\spxentry{classes.pySp3}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Project: Parallel.Archive
Date: 2/22/17 3:27 PM
Author: Demian D. Gomez

\sphinxAtStartPar
AUG 2 2023: changed the default behavior (due to new naming convention from IGS)
the {\color{red}\bfseries{}sp3\_} keywords in gnss\_data.cfg incorporate
sp3\_ac: an ordered list of the precedence of Analysis Centers to get orbits from (IGS, JPL, COD, etc)
sp3\_cs: an ordered list of campaign/project specifications that determines which product to download. In general the
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
first one is R03,R02,etc and then OPS
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
sp3\_st: an ordered list of solution types. In general the first one is FIN and then RAP

\sphinxAtStartPar
if the new orbit name scheme results in no match, then by default we fall back to the old naming convention using the
ACs specified in sp3\_ac using the following download tries (where xx or xxx is the lowercase AC code) xx2, xxx, xxr
The sp3\_type\_x and sp3\_altr\_x are now deprecated.

\subsection{classes.pyTerminal module}
\label{\detokenize{classes:module-classes.pyTerminal}}\label{\detokenize{classes:classes-pyterminal-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!classes.pyTerminal@\spxentry{classes.pyTerminal}}\index{classes.pyTerminal@\spxentry{classes.pyTerminal}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{ProgressBar (class in classes.pyTerminal)@\spxentry{ProgressBar}\spxextra{class in classes.pyTerminal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyTerminal.ProgressBar}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{ }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyTerminal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{ProgressBar}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{term}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{header}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A 3\sphinxhyphen{}line progress bar, which looks like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
                        \PYG{n}{Header}
\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{o}{\PYGZpc{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{o}{==}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{p}{]}
                   \PYG{n}{progress} \PYG{n}{message}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The progress bar is colored, if the terminal supports color
output; and adjusts to the width of the terminal.

\index{TerminalController (class in classes.pyTerminal)@\spxentry{TerminalController}\spxextra{class in classes.pyTerminal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyTerminal.TerminalController}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{ }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyTerminal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{TerminalController}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{term\_stream=\textless{}\_io.TextIOWrapper name=\textquotesingle{}\textless{}stdout\textgreater{}\textquotesingle{} mode=\textquotesingle{}w\textquotesingle{} encoding=\textquotesingle{}utf\sphinxhyphen{}8\textquotesingle{}\textgreater{}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A class that can be used to portably generate formatted output to
a terminal.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{TerminalController} defines a set of instance variables whose
values are initialized to the control sequence necessary to
perform a given action.  These can be simply included in normal
output to the terminal:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{term} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{TerminalController}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{This is }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n}{term}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{GREEN}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{green}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{n}{term}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{NORMAL}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Alternatively, the \sphinxtitleref{render()} method can used, which replaces
‘\$\{action\}’ with the string required to perform ‘action’:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{term} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{TerminalController}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n+nb}{print} \PYG{n}{term}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{render}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{This is \PYGZdl{}}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}GREEN\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{green\PYGZdl{}}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}NORMAL\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the terminal doesn’t support a given action, then the value of
the corresponding instance variable will be set to ‘’.  As a
result, the above code will still work on terminals that do not
support color, except that their output will not be colored.
Also, this means that you can test whether the terminal supports a
given action by simply testing the truth value of the
corresponding instance variable:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{term} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{TerminalController}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{term}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CLEAR\PYGZus{}SCREEN}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }    \PYG{n+nb}{print} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{This terminal supports clearning the screen.}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Finally, if the width and height of the terminal are known, then
they will be stored in the \sphinxtitleref{COLS} and \sphinxtitleref{LINES} attributes.

\subsection{classes.pyVoronoi module}
\label{\detokenize{classes:module-classes.pyVoronoi}}\label{\detokenize{classes:classes-pyvoronoi-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!classes.pyVoronoi@\spxentry{classes.pyVoronoi}}\index{classes.pyVoronoi@\spxentry{classes.pyVoronoi}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Author: Tyler Reddy

\sphinxAtStartPar
The purpose of this Python module is to provide utility code for handling spherical Voronoi Diagrams.
\index{IntersectionError@\spxentry{IntersectionError}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.IntersectionError}}

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Exception}}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{calculate\_Vincenty\_distance\_between\_spherical\_points() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{calculate\_Vincenty\_distance\_between\_spherical\_points()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.calculate_Vincenty_distance_between_spherical_points}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyVoronoi.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{calculate\_Vincenty\_distance\_between\_spherical\_points}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{cartesian\_array\_1}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{cartesian\_array\_2}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{sphere\_radius}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Apparently, the special case of the Vincenty formula (\sphinxurl{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great-circle\_distance}) may be the most accurate method for calculating great\sphinxhyphen{}circle distances.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{calculate\_and\_sum\_up\_inner\_sphere\_surface\_angles\_Voronoi\_polygon() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{calculate\_and\_sum\_up\_inner\_sphere\_surface\_angles\_Voronoi\_polygon()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.calculate_and_sum_up_inner_sphere_surface_angles_Voronoi_polygon}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyVoronoi.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{calculate\_and\_sum\_up\_inner\_sphere\_surface\_angles\_Voronoi\_polygon}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{array\_ordered\_Voronoi\_polygon\_vertices}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{sphere\_radius}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Takes an array of ordered Voronoi polygon vertices (for a single generator) and calculates the sum of the inner angles on the sphere surface. The resulting value is theta in the equation provided here: \sphinxurl{http://mathworld.wolfram.com/SphericalPolygon.html}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{calculate\_haversine\_distance\_between\_spherical\_points() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{calculate\_haversine\_distance\_between\_spherical\_points()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.calculate_haversine_distance_between_spherical_points}}

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Calculate the haversine\sphinxhyphen{}based distance between two points on the surface of a sphere. Should be more accurate than the arc cosine strategy. See, for example: \sphinxurl{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haversine\_formula}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{calculate\_surface\_area\_of\_a\_spherical\_Voronoi\_polygon() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{calculate\_surface\_area\_of\_a\_spherical\_Voronoi\_polygon()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Calculate the surface area of a polygon on the surface of a sphere. Based on equation provided here: \sphinxurl{http://mathworld.wolfram.com/LHuiliersTheorem.html}
Decompose into triangles, calculate excess for each

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{calculate\_surface\_area\_of\_planar\_polygon\_in\_3D\_space() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{calculate\_surface\_area\_of\_planar\_polygon\_in\_3D\_space()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\index{convert\_cartesian\_array\_to\_spherical\_array() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{convert\_cartesian\_array\_to\_spherical\_array()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.convert_cartesian_array_to_spherical_array}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyVoronoi.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convert\_cartesian\_array\_to\_spherical\_array}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{coord\_array}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{angle\_measure}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}radians\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Take shape (N,3) cartesian coord\_array and return an array of the same shape in spherical polar form (r, theta, phi). Based on StackOverflow response: \sphinxurl{http://stackoverflow.com/a/4116899}
use radians for the angles by default, degrees if angle\_measure == ‘degrees’

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{convert\_spherical\_array\_to\_cartesian\_array() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{convert\_spherical\_array\_to\_cartesian\_array()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.convert_spherical_array_to_cartesian_array}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyVoronoi.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convert\_spherical\_array\_to\_cartesian\_array}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{spherical\_coord\_array}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{angle\_measure}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}radians\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Take shape (N,3) spherical\_coord\_array (r,theta,phi) and return an array of the same shape in cartesian coordinate form (x,y,z). Based on the equations provided at: \sphinxurl{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List\_of\_common\_coordinate\_transformations\#From\_spherical\_coordinates}
use radians for the angles by default, degrees if angle\_measure == ‘degrees’

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{filter\_polygon\_vertex\_coordinates\_for\_extreme\_proximity() (in module classes.pyVoronoi)@\spxentry{filter\_polygon\_vertex\_coordinates\_for\_extreme\_proximity()}\spxextra{in module classes.pyVoronoi}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{classes:classes.pyVoronoi.filter_polygon_vertex_coordinates_for_extreme_proximity}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{classes.pyVoronoi.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{filter\_polygon\_vertex\_coordinates\_for\_extreme\_proximity}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{array\_ordered\_Voronoi\_polygon\_vertices}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{sphere\_radius}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Merge (take the midpoint of) polygon vertices that are judged to be extremely close together and return the filtered polygon vertex array. The purpose is to alleviate numerical complications that may arise during surface area calculations involving polygons with ultra\sphinxhyphen{}close / nearly coplanar vertices.

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsubsection{AlterETM.py \sphinxhyphen{} CLI interface}
\label{\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py---CLI-interface}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Program to alter the default ETM parameters for each station. The command can be executed on several stations at the same time. It is also possible to alter parameters for PPP and GAMIT simultaneously.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{AlterETM}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{py} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{h}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{fun} \PYG{n}{function} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{argument} \PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{soln} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{ppp}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{gamit}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{ppp}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{n}{gamit}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]}
            \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{]}
            \PYG{n+nb}{all}\PYG{o}{|}\PYG{n}{net}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{stnm} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{all}\PYG{o}{|}\PYG{n}{net}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{stnm} \PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{AlterETM.py positional arguments}
\label{\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py-positional-arguments}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py-all|net.stnm}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{all|net.stnm}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} List of networks/stations to process given in {[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} (separated by spaces; if {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all stations with that name will be processed). Use keyword \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}all\textquotesingle{}}} to process all stations in the database. If {[}net{]}.all is given, all stations from network {[}net{]} will be processed. Three letter ISO 3166 international standard codes can be provided (always in upper case) to select all stations within a country. If a station name is given using a * in front (e.g. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}igs.pwro or {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}pwro) then the station will be removed from the list. If {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}net.all or ISO country code was used (e.g. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}igs.all or {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}ARG), then remove the stations within this group. Wildcards are accepted using the regex postgres convention. Use {[}{]} to provide character ranges (e.g. ars.at1{[}3\sphinxhyphen{}5{]} or ars.{[}a\sphinxhyphen{}b{]}x01). Char \%\% matches any string (e.g. ars.at\%\%). Char | represents the OR operator that can be used to select one string or another (e.g. ars.at1{[}1|2{]} to choose at11 and at12). To specify a wildcard using a single character, use \_ (equivalent to ? in POSIX regular expressions). Alternatively, a file with the station list can be provided (using all the same conventions described above). When using a file, * can be replaced with \sphinxhyphen{} for clarity in removing stations from .all lists (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{AlterETM.py options}
\label{\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py-options}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py--h}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}h}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py---help}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}help}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} show this help message and exit

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py--fun}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}fun}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FUNCTION}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py---function_type}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}function\_type}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FUNCTION}} \sphinxhyphen{} R|Specifies the type of function to work with. Can be polynomial (p), jump (j), periodic (q) or bulk earthquake jump removal (t). Each one accepts a list of arguments.
p \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{terms\}}} where terms equals the number of polynomial terms in the ETM, i.e. terms = 2 is constant velocity and terms = 3 is velocity + acceleration, etc.
j \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{action\}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{type\}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{date\}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{relax\}}} where action can be + or \sphinxhyphen{}. A + indicates that a jump should be added while a \sphinxhyphen{} means that an existing jump should be removed; type = 0 is a mechanic jump and 1 is a geophysical jump; date is the date of the event in all the accepted formats (yyyy/mm/dd yyyy\_doy gpswk\sphinxhyphen{}wkday fyear); and relax is a list of relaxation times for the logarithmic decays (only used when type = 1, they are ignored when type = 0).
q \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{periods\}}} where periods is a list expressed in days (1 yr = 365.25).
t \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{max\_magnitude\}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{stack\_name\}}} removes any earthquake Mw \textless{}= max\_magnitude from the specified stations’ trajectory models; if GAMIT solutions are invoked, provide the stack\_name to obtain the ETMs of the stations.
m \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{stack\_name\}}} {[}start\_date{]} {[}end\_date|days{]} removes mechanical jumps between given dates from the specified stations’ trajectory models; if no dates are provided, remove all mechanical jumps. If only first date is provided, remove starting at that date until today. Can also specify \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{start\_date\}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{days\}}} to add to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{start\_date\}}}. Provide the stack\_name to obtain the ETMs of the stations. If PPP solutions only (\sphinxhyphen{}soln ppp), stack\_name is ignored. If both solutions are indicated (or \sphinxhyphen{}soln is not specified) then stack\_name must be provided. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}{]}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py--soln}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}soln}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SOLUTION\_TYPE}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py---solution_type}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}solution\_type}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SOLUTION\_TYPE}} \sphinxhyphen{} Specifies the type of solution that this command will affect. If left empty, the ETMs for both PPP and GAMIT will be affected. Otherwise, specify gamit to insert or remove the function on GAMIT ETMs only or ppp to insert or remove the function on PPP ETMs only. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}\textquotesingle{}ppp\textquotesingle{}, \textquotesingle{}gamit\textquotesingle{}{]}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py--print}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}print}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:AlterETM.py---print_params}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}print\_params}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Print the parameters present in the database for the selected stations.

\end{itemize}

\subsection{com.ArchiveService module}
\label{\detokenize{com:module-com.ArchiveService}}\label{\detokenize{com:com-archiveservice-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!com.ArchiveService@\spxentry{com.ArchiveService}}\index{com.ArchiveService@\spxentry{com.ArchiveService}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Project: Parallel.Archive
Date: 3/19/17 11:41 AM
Author: Demian D. Gomez


\subsubsection{ArchiveService}
\label{\detokenize{com:archiveservice}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Main script that scans the repository for new rinex files.
It PPPs the rinex files and searches the database for stations (within configured distance in stations table)
with the same station 4 letter code.
If the station exists in the db, it moves the file to the archive and adds the new file to the “rinex” table.
if the station doesn’t exist, then it incorporates the station with a special NetworkCode (???) and leaves the
file in the repo until you assign the correct NetworkCode and add the station information.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is invoked just by calling python ArchiveService.py
Requires the config file gnss\_data.cfg (in the running folder)

\sphinxAtStartPar
Options:
\textendash{}purge\_locks: deletes any locked files from repository and database
\textendash{}no\_parallel: runs without parallelizing the execution

Antenna has to exist in ATX file provided in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{atx\_file\}}}. Radome will be set to NONE by default. \paragraph{DownloadSources.py positional arguments}
\label{\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py-positional-arguments}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py-all|net.stnm}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{all|net.stnm}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} List of networks/stations to process given in {[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} (separated by spaces; if {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all stations with that name will be processed). Use keyword \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}all\textquotesingle{}}} to process all stations in the database. If {[}net{]}.all is given, all stations from network {[}net{]} will be processed. Alternatively, a file with the station list can be provided. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{DownloadSources.py options}
\label{\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py-options}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py--h}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}h}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py---help}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}help}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} show this help message and exit

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py--date}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}date}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DATE\_START|DATE\_END}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py---date_range}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}date\_range}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DATE\_START|DATE\_END}} \sphinxhyphen{} Date range to check given as {[}date\_start{]} or {[}date\_start{]} and {[}date\_end{]}. Allowed formats are yyyy.doy or yyyy/mm/dd.. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py--win}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}win}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DAYS}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py---window}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}window}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DAYS}} \sphinxhyphen{} Download data from a given time window determined by today \sphinxhyphen{} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{days\}}}. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py--np}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}np}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSources.py---noparallel}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}noparallel}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Execute command without parallelization.

\end{itemize}

\index{query\_yes\_no() (in module com.DownloadSourcesFill)@\spxentry{query\_yes\_no()}\spxextra{in module com.DownloadSourcesFill}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{com:com.DownloadSourcesFill.query_yes_no}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{com.DownloadSourcesFill.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{query\_yes\_no}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{question}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{default}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}yes\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Ask a yes/no question via raw\_input() and return their answer.

\sphinxAtStartPar
“question” is a string that is presented to the user.
“default” is the presumed answer if the user just hits \textless{}Enter\textgreater{}.
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It must be “yes” (the default), “no” or None (meaning
an answer is required of the user).
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The “answer” return value is True for “yes” or False for “no”.
code obtained from \sphinxurl{https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3041986/apt-command-line-interface-like-yes-no-input}

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{DownloadSourcesFill.py positional arguments}
\label{\detokenize{com:DownloadSourcesFill.py-positional-arguments}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:DownloadSourcesFill.py-all|net.stnm}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{all|net.stnm}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} List of networks/stations to process given in {[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} (separated by spaces; if {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all stations with that name will be processed). Use keyword \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}all\textquotesingle{}}} to process all stations in the database. If {[}net{]}.all is given, all stations from network {[}net{]} will be processed. Three letter ISO 3166 international standard codes can be provided (always in upper case) to select all stations within a country. If a station name is given using a * in front (e.g. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}igs.pwro or {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}pwro) then the station will be removed from the list. If {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}net.all or ISO country code was used (e.g. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}igs.all or {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}ARG), then remove the stations within this group. Wildcards are accepted using the regex postgres convention. Use {[}{]} to provide character ranges (e.g. ars.at1{[}3\sphinxhyphen{}5{]} or ars.{[}a\sphinxhyphen{}b{]}x01). Char \%\% matches any string (e.g. ars.at\%\%). Char | represents the OR operator that can be used to select one string or another (e.g. ars.at1{[}1|2{]} to choose at11 and at12). To specify a wildcard using a single character, use \_ (equivalent to ? in POSIX regular expressions). Alternatively, a file with the station list can be provided (using all the same conventions described above). When using a file, * can be replaced with \sphinxhyphen{} for clarity in removing stations from .all lists (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{DownloadSourcesFill.py options}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

If only {[}date\_start{]} is given, then {[}date\_end{]} is today. If an integer is provided, then {[}date\_start{]} is today minus value provided. Allowed formats are wwww\sphinxhyphen{}d, yyyy\_ddd, yyyy/mm/dd or fyear. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

If multiple sources use the same FQDM, then all will be probed to search for RINEX data matching the station list provided. Be careful with hitting a single server with too many requests! (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}})

Searches for data gaps in the rinex table

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Prints the station info records

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
renames or merges two stations into one

\end{itemize}

\paragraph{IntegrityCheck.py positional arguments}
\label{\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py-positional-arguments}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py-all|net.stnm}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{all|net.stnm}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} List of networks/stations to process given in {[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} (separated by spaces; if {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all stations with that name will be processed). Use keyword \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}all\textquotesingle{}}} to process all stations in the database. If {[}net{]}.all is given, all stations from network {[}net{]} will be processed. Alternatevily, a file with the station list can be provided. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\end{itemize}

Can be specified in wwww\sphinxhyphen{}d, yyyy\_ddd, yyyy/mm/dd or fyear format (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

If argument = \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"fix"}} and a RINEX file does not exist, remove the record. PPP records or gamit\_soln are deleted. If argument = \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"report"}} then just list the missing files. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--rnx_count}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}rnx\_count}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---rinex_count}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}rinex\_count}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Count the total number of RINEX files (unique station\sphinxhyphen{}days) per day for a given time interval.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--stnr}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}stnr}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---station_info_rinex}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}station\_info\_rinex}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Check that the receiver serial number in the rinex headers agrees with the station info receiver serial number.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--stns}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}stns}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---station_info_solutions}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}station\_info\_solutions}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Check that the PPP hash values match the station info hash.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--stnp}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}stnp}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IGNORE\_DAYS}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---station_info_proposed}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}station\_info\_proposed}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IGNORE\_DAYS}} \sphinxhyphen{} Output a proposed station.info using the RINEX metadata. Optional, specify {[}ignore\_days{]} to ignore station.info records \textless{}= days. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--stnc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}stnc}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---station_info_check}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}station\_info\_check}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Check the consistency of the station information records in the database. Date range does not apply. Also, check that the RINEX files fall within a valid station information record.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--g}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}g}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IGNORE\_DAYS}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---data_gaps}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}data\_gaps}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IGNORE\_DAYS}} \sphinxhyphen{} Check the RINEX files in the database and look for gaps (missing days). Optional, {[}ignore\_days{]} with the smallest gap to display. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--gg}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}gg}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---graphical_gaps}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}graphical\_gaps}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Visually output RINEX gaps for stations.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--sc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}sc}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SPATIAL\_COHERENCE}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---spatial_coherence}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}spatial\_coherence}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SPATIAL\_COHERENCE}} \sphinxhyphen{} Check that the RINEX files correspond to the stations they are linked to using their PPP coordinate. If keyword {[}exclude{]} or {[}delete{]}, add the PPP solution to the excluded table or delete the PPP solution. If {[}noop{]}, then only report but do not exlude or delete. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--print}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}print}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRINT\_STNINFO}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---print_stninfo}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}print\_stninfo}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRINT\_STNINFO}} \sphinxhyphen{} Output the station info to stdout. {[}long{]} outputs the full line of the station info. {[}short{]} outputs a short version (better for screen visualization). (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--r}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}r}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NET.STNM}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---rename}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}rename}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NET.STNM}} \sphinxhyphen{} Takes the data from the station list and renames (merges) it to net.stnm. It also changes the rinex filenames in the archive to match those of the new destiny station. Only a single station can be given as the origin and destiny. Limit the date range using the \sphinxhyphen{}d option. If origin station is empty (no RINEX files) after rename/merge, the station is deleted from the database if \textendash{}delete\_station is invoked. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--del_stn}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}del\_stn}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---delete_station}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}delete\_station}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Switch to enable station deletion after rename/merge operation. Only works when invoking \textendash{}rename.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--es}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}es}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{START\_DATE\}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---exclude_solutions}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}exclude\_solutions}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{START\_DATE\}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Exclude PPP solutions (by adding them to the excluded table) between \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{start\_date\}}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{end\_date\}}} (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--del}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}del}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{START\_DATE\}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---delete_rinex}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}delete\_rinex}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{START\_DATE\}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Delete RINEX files (and associated solutions, PPP and GAMIT) from archive between \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{start\_date\}}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{end\_date\}}} with completion \textless{}= \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{completion\}}}. Completion ranges form 1.0 to 0.0. Use 1.0 to delete all data. Operation cannot be undone! (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py--np}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}np}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:IntegrityCheck.py---noparallel}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}noparallel}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Execute command without parallelization.

\end{itemize}

\paragraph{PlotETM.py positional arguments}
\label{\detokenize{com:PlotETM.py-positional-arguments}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotETM.py-stnlist}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{stnlist}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} List of networks/stations to process given in {[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} (separated by spaces; if {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all stations with that name will be processed). Use keyword \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}all\textquotesingle{}}} to process all stations in the database. If {[}net{]}.all is given, all stations from network {[}net{]} will be processed. Three letter ISO 3166 international standard codes can be provided (always in upper case) to select all stations within a country. If a station name is given using a * in front (e.g. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}igs.pwro or {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}pwro) then the station will be removed from the list. If {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}net.all or ISO country code was used (e.g. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}igs.all or {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}ARG), then remove the stations within this group. Wildcards are accepted using the regex postgres convention. Use {[}{]} to provide character ranges (e.g. ars.at1{[}3\sphinxhyphen{}5{]} or ars.{[}a\sphinxhyphen{}b{]}x01). Char \%\% matches any string (e.g. ars.at\%\%). Char | represents the OR operator that can be used to select one string or another (e.g. ars.at1{[}1|2{]} to choose at11 and at12). To specify a wildcard using a single character, use \_ (equivalent to ? in POSIX regular expressions). Alternatively, a file with the station list can be provided (using all the same conventions described above). When using a file, * can be replaced with \sphinxhyphen{} for clarity in removing stations from .all lists (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{PlotETM.py options}
\label{\detokenize{com:PlotETM.py-options}}\begin{itemize}

\paragraph{PlotMapView.py options}
\label{\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py-options}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--h}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}h}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---help}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}help}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} show this help message and exit

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--stn}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}stn}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{STATION LIST\}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---stations}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}stations}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{STATION LIST\}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Specify the list of networks/stations given in {[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} that will be filtered using the selected field specifications. If {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all stations with that name will be processed.Alternatively, a file with the station list can be provided. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}{]}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--inter}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}inter}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{INTERSEISMIC\_MODEL\}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---interseismic_model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}interseismic\_model}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{INTERSEISMIC\_MODEL\}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Interseismic removal is done using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{interseismic\_grid\}}}. (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--post}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}post}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{EVENT\_DATE\} {[}EVENT\_DATE\_1{]} {[}EVENT\_DATE\_2{]} ... {[}EVENT\_GRID\_1{]} {[}EVENT\_GRID\_2{]} ...}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---postseismic}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}postseismic}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{EVENT\_DATE\} {[}EVENT\_DATE\_1{]} {[}EVENT\_DATE\_2{]} ... {[}EVENT\_GRID\_1{]} {[}EVENT\_GRID\_2{]} ...}} \sphinxhyphen{} Interseismic removal is done using the grid provided in \textendash{}interseismic\_model. The event postseimic to be plotted correspond to seismic event given in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{event\_date\}}}. Additionally, provide {[}event\_date\_n{]} and {[}event\_grid\_n{]} if a previous postsiesmic processes should be removed from the ETMs. If no {[}event\_date\_n{]} are given, then any previous events are ignored (but they could still be present in the ETM fit). (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--co}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}co}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{COSEISMIC\_GRID\}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---coseismic}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}coseismic}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{COSEISMIC\_GRID\}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Coseismic grid to use for stations that were not active by the time of the event. This assumes that you are providing the grid of the event specific in \sphinxhyphen{}post (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--dir}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}dir}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DIRECTORY}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---directory}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}directory}}}}}} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DIRECTORY}} \sphinxhyphen{} Directory to save the resulting PNG files. If not specified, assumed to be the production directory (default: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{None}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py--missing}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}missing}}}}}}, {\hyperref[\detokenize{com:PlotMapView.py---plot_missing_solutions}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstylestrong{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}plot\_missing\_solutions}}}}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Plot the missing solutions in the ETMs stored in the KMZ file (might take longer to produce the file).

\end{itemize}

\subsection{com.Read\_M\sphinxhyphen{}file module}

\subsection{com.ScanArchive module}
\label{\detokenize{com:module-com.ScanArchive}}\label{\detokenize{com:com-scanarchive-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!com.ScanArchive@\spxentry{com.ScanArchive}}\index{com.ScanArchive@\spxentry{com.ScanArchive}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Project: Parallel.Archive
Date: 02/16/2017
Author: Demian D. Gomez

\sphinxAtStartPar
Main routines to load the RINEX files to the database, load station
information, run PPP on the archive files and obtain the OTL coefficients
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{usage: pyScanArchive.py {[}\sphinxhyphen{}h{]} {[}\sphinxhyphen{}rinex{]} {[}\sphinxhyphen{}otl{]}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
{[}\sphinxhyphen{}stninfo {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}{]}
{[}\sphinxhyphen{}ppp {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}{]}
{[}\sphinxhyphen{}rehash {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}{]} {[}\sphinxhyphen{}np{]}
all|net.stnm {[}all|net.stnm …{]}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Archive operations Main Program
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{positional arguments:}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{all|net.stnm          List of networks/stations to process given in}
\sphinxAtStartPar
{[}net{]}.{[}stnm{]} format or just {[}stnm{]} (separated by
spaces; if {[}stnm{]} is not unique in the database, all
stations with that name will be processed). Use
keyword ‘all’ to process all stations in the database.
If {[}net{]}.all is given, all stations from network {[}net{]}
will be processed. Alternatevily, a file with the
station list can be provided.

\end{description}

\sphinxlineitem{optional arguments:}\begin{optionlist}{3cm}
\item [\sphinxhyphen{}h, \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}help]  
\sphinxAtStartPar
show this help message and exit
\item [\sphinxhyphen{}rinex, \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}rinex]  
\sphinxAtStartPar
Scan the current archive for RINEX 2/3 files.
\item [\sphinxhyphen{}otl, \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}ocean\_loading]  
\sphinxAtStartPar
Calculate ocean loading coefficients.
\end{optionlist}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxhyphen{}stninfo {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}, \textendash{}station\_info {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Insert station information to the database. If no
arguments are given, then scan the archive for station
info files and use their location (folder) to
determine the network to use during insertion. Only
stations in the station list will be processed. If a
filename is provided, then scan that file only, in
which case a second argument specifies the network to
use during insertion. Eg: \sphinxhyphen{}stninfo \textasciitilde{}/station.info arg.
In cases where multiple networks are being processed,
the network argument will be used to desambiguate
station code conflicts. Eg: pyScanArchive all \sphinxhyphen{}stninfo
\textasciitilde{}/station.info arg \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} if a station named igm1 exists
in networks ‘igs’ and ‘arg’, only ‘arg.igm1’ will get
the station information insert. Use keyword ‘stdin’ to
read the station information data from the pipeline.

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxhyphen{}ppp {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}, \textendash{}ppp {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Run ppp on the rinex files in the database. Append
{[}date\_start{]} and (optionally) {[}date\_end{]} to limit the
range of the processing. Allowed formats are yyyy.doy
or yyyy/mm/dd. Append keyword ‘hash’ to the end to
check the PPP hash values against the station
information records. If hash doesn’t match,
recalculate the PPP solutions.

\sphinxlineitem{\sphinxhyphen{}rehash {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}, \textendash{}rehash {[}argument {[}argument …{]}{]}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Check PPP hash against station information hash.
Rehash PPP solutions to match the station information
hash without recalculating the PPP solution.
Optionally append {[}date\_start{]} and (optionally)
{[}date\_end{]} to limit the rehashing time window. Allowed
formats are yyyy.doy or yyyy/mm/dd.

\end{description}
\begin{optionlist}{3cm}
\item [\sphinxhyphen{}np, \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}noparallel]  
\sphinxAtStartPar
Execute command without parallelization.
\end{optionlist}

\end{description}
\index{Encoder (class in com.ScanArchive)@\spxentry{Encoder}\spxextra{class in com.ScanArchive}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\index{default() (com.ScanArchive.Encoder method)@\spxentry{default()}\spxextra{com.ScanArchive.Encoder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{com:com.ScanArchive.Encoder.default}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{default}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{o}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Implement this method in a subclass such that it returns
a serializable object for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{o}}, or calls the base implementation
(to raise a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TypeError}}).

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example, to support arbitrary iterators, you could
implement default like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{default}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{o}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{try}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{iterable} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{iter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{o}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{except} \PYG{n+ne}{TypeError}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{pass}
    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb}{list}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{iterable}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Let the base class default method raise the TypeError}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{JSONEncoder}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{default}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{o}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

Archive operations Main Program
